courses.name: Intermediate Algebra
courses.description: Preparatory algebra course. Does not count toward degree credits.

courses.name: Pre-Calculus
courses.description: Preparation for calculus. Covers functions, trigonometry, and algebraic techniques.

courses.name: Pre-Calculus for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description: Accelerated pre-calculus for STEM students. Leads directly into MATH 241.

courses.name: Discrete Mathematics I
courses.description: Logic, sets, proof techniques, combinatorics, graph theory. Foundational for upper-level math.

courses.name: Calculus I
courses.description: Single-variable differential calculus. Not the typical starting point for math majors — most start with MATH 241 or 242.

courses.name: Finite Mathematics with Applications
courses.description: Linear algebra and probability with applications to business and social sciences.

courses.name: Integrated Calculus IA
courses.description: First part of a two-semester sequence that integrates pre-calculus and Calculus I.

courses.name: Integrated Calculus IB
courses.description: Second part of the integrated calculus sequence. Equivalent to MATH 241 upon completion.

courses.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus A
courses.description: Single-variable calculus: limits, derivatives, integrals, fundamental theorem. Standard entry point for math majors.

courses.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus B
courses.description: Continuation of calculus: techniques of integration, series, parametric equations, polar coordinates.

courses.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus C
courses.description: Multivariable calculus: partial derivatives, multiple integrals, vector calculus, Stokes theorem.

courses.name: An Introduction to Proof
courses.description: Bridge course to upper-level math. Proof techniques,Basic set operations, relations, equivalence relations, functions, inverse functions, cardinality, order properties of real numbers, least upper bound, greatest lower bound, completeness axiom, topology of reals, complex numbers.

courses.name: Ordinary Differential Equations
courses.description: First and second order ODEs, systems, Laplace transforms, applications.

courses.name: Applied Mathematics for the Biological Sciences
courses.description: Mathematical modeling in biology using differential equations and computation.

courses.name: Historical Development of Mathematical Concepts and Ideas
courses.description: History of mathematics. Satisfies College second writing requirement. WARNING: Does NOT count as a restricted elective for BS Math.

courses.name: Discrete Mathematics II
courses.description: Advanced combinatorics, graph theory, algorithms. Builds on MATH 210.

courses.name: Elementary Linear Algebra
courses.description: Matrix algebra, vector spaces, eigenvalues, linear transformations. Fundamental for almost all upper-level math.

courses.name: Probability Theory and Simulation Methods
courses.description: Probability distributions, random variables, expectation, simulation. Foundation for statistics.

courses.name: Engineering Mathematics I
courses.description: Solutions of linear algebraic equations, Gauss elimination, vector spaces, subspaces, linear dependence, linear ordinary differential equations of 2nd order and higher, initial value problems, eigenvalues, coupled linear ordinary differential equations, nonlinear differential equations, with engineering applications.

courses.name: Engineering Mathematics II
courses.description: Laplace transform, application to constant coefficient ordinary differential equations, scalar and vector fields, Laplacian, line integrals, divergence theorem, Stokes’ theorem, Fourier series, orthogonality, diffusion equation, Laplace’s equation, wave equation, separation of variables, with engineering applications.

courses.name: Engineering Mathematics III
courses.description: Numerical Methods in engineering, linear and non-linear algebraic equations, numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, Runge-Kutta methods, boundary value problems, finite differences, diffusion, Laplace equation, applications to engineering problems with programming.

courses.name: Introduction to Real Analysis
courses.description: A rigorous treatment of one variable calculus. Topics will include sequences of real numbers, limit theorems, monotone sequences, Cauchy sequences, Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem, continuity, uniform continuity, differentiability and Riemann integral. A historical perspective on the development of these topics will be provided.

courses.name: Computational Mathematics I
courses.description: Floating point numbers; conditioning and stability; LU, Cholesky, and QR factorizations; square and overdetermined linear systems; Newton and quasi-Newton rootfinding methods; piecewise polynomials for interpolation, integration, and finite differences; explicit methods for initial-value problems.

courses.name: Computational Mathematics II
courses.description: Advanced numerical methods for ODEs and PDEs.

courses.name: Mathematical Statistics
courses.description: Introduction to mathematical aspects of statistics. Topics include exploratory data analysis, parameter estimation, maximum likelihood method, testing of hypothesis, confidence intervals and others. Includes application of a computer software package to perform data analysis.

courses.name: Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: Basic properties of the integers and the rationals, fields of quotients, polynomial rings, root-finding, introduction to groups, rings and fields. A historical perspective on the development of the notion of number and algebraic structure.

courses.name: Contemporary Applications of Mathematics
courses.description: Real-world applications of mathematics. Core course AND can satisfy the college second writing requirement.

courses.name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations
prerequisites: MATH302 or MATH305 or MATH342 or MATH352
courses.description: Heat equation, wave equation, Laplace equation, Fourier methods.

courses.name: General Computer Science for Engineers
courses.description: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in a general-purpose language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles, and issues that arise in engineering..

courses.name: Introduction to Systems Programming
courses.description: Principles of computer systems programming for software and hardware platforms to achieve efficient resource usage. Topics include the C programming language, memory management, and awareness of system constraints and interfacing. Projects include programming embedded systems and interactive objects.

courses.name: Data Structures
courses.description: Review of data type abstraction, recursion, arrays, stacks, queues, multiple stacks and linked lists. Emphasis on dynamic storage management, garbage collection, trees, graphs, tables, sorting and searching.

courses.name: First-Year Writing
courses.description: University-required writing course. Must earn C- or better.

courses.name: Written Communications in Business
courses.description: Business writing. Satisfies CAS second writing requirement.

courses.name: Technical Writing
courses.description: Technical and scientific writing. Satisfies CAS second writing requirement.

proof_track: MATH210 + MATH242 -> MATH245 -> MATH401 or MATH451
